Event Schedule | Transportation | Hotels | Dining  | Things to do 

Visit the exhibition

Celebrating the recent acquisition of editorial cartoonist Patrick Oliphant’s voluminous archive, Oliphant: Unpacking the Archive juxtaposes cartoon drawings, sculptures, and paintings with manuscripts, correspondence, and personal effects. It tells the fullest story yet of the most influential caricaturist of American politics and culture in the last half century.  The exhibition will be open from 9:00 am–7:00 pm daily in the Main Gallery of Harrison/Small.

Event Schedule

Tuesday, September 24, 2019

Cartooning the White House: Stories and lessons from the career of Patrick Oliphant

Newcomb Hall Theatre **PLEASE NOTE CHANGE OF VENUE** 
2:00–5:00 pm 

The Miller Center will host two panels exploring Oliphant and the Scholar and Oliphant and the Practitioner. Speakers, whose expertise touches every U.S. president from Lyndon B. Johnson to Barack Obama, include Mary Kate Cary, George H. W. Bush speechwriter, documentarian, and political analyst; Kent Germany, Associate Professor of History at the University of South Carolina; Ken Hughes, renowned scholar of the secret Nixon tapes; Chris Lu, Teresa A. Sullivan Practitioner Senior Fellow at the Miller Center; Chester Pach, Associate Professor of History at Ohio University; Robert Strong, William Lyne Wilson Professor of Politics at Washington & Lee University; and Philip Zelikow, White Burkett Miller Professor of History and J. Wilson Newman Professor of Governance at UVA and former counselor of the Department of State under George W. Bush. 

Michael Nelson, Fulmer Professor of Political Science at Rhodes College and Senior Fellow with the Miller Center, will moderate both panels. For more information, please contact Cristina Lopez-Gottardi Chao at cl4zx@virginia.edu or 434-924-4561.

Signed books will be available for purchase at this event.

Reception and screening of “Patrick Oliphant Documentary” (Invitation only)

Violet Crown Cinema, 200 West Main Street
6:15–7:45 pm 

Violet Crown Cinema will screen an abbreviated version of a work-in-progress documentary film celebrating the extraordinary life and career of Patrick Oliphant. Bill Banowsky, producer of the documentary and founder of Violet Crown Cinemas, will host a reception prior to the screening. The screening will begin at 7 pm.

 

Wednesday, September 25, 2019

Welcome Coffee (Invitation only)

Boar's Head Resort
200 Ednam Drive
Charlottesville, VA 22903
10:00 am–12:00 noon

Rotunda Tour (Invitation only)

1826 University Avenue
1:30–2:30 pm

Tour the UVA Rotunda and Academic Village, a UNESCO World Heritage site, with Vice Provost for Academic Outreach and Professor of Architectural History Louis P. Nelson, and Senior Historic Preservation Planner Brian Hogg.

Oliphant: Unpacking the Archive Exhibition and Reception 

Mary and David Harrison Institute/Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, 160 McCormick Road
5:00–6:30 pm 

Oliphant: Unpacking the Archive (September 2019–May 2020) celebrates Patrick Oliphant’s recent donation of his archive of over 7,000 drawings, watercolors, prints, sculptures, and sketchbooks. Complementing the original art is a wealth of material documenting this Pulitzer Prize-winning political cartoonist’s career. 

The forty original drawings and numerous sketches in this exhibition, covering presidencies from Johnson to Obama, reveal the creative process behind Oliphant’s incisive and often devastatingly funny political commentary. Exhibition co-curators Elizabeth Hutton Turner and Molly Schwartzburg will be on hand to share their favorite items on display, discuss their process in curating the exhibition, and talk about what they have discovered in the archive so far. 

Signed books will be available for purchase at this event.

Dinner with Keynote Speaker Maureen Dowd (Invitation only)

Farmington Country Club Ballroom, 1625 Country Club Circle
7:15–9:30 pm

A celebratory dinner in honor of Patrick Oliphant and in recognition of his lifetime of contributions to culture and politics. New York Times columnist Maureen Dowd, the renowned reporter, bestselling author, and winner of the 1999 Pulitzer Prize for distinguished commentary, will be the keynote speaker. Donald Lamm, literary agent and former CEO of W.W. Norton Publishing Company, will act as master of ceremonies. Dress for this event is cocktail attire.

 

Thursday, September 26, 2019

Editorial Cartoons and the First Amendment: The Supreme Court Decision that Saved Political Satire

Caplin Pavilion at the University of Virginia School of Law, 580 Massie Road
11:30 am–12:45 pm

A conversation about First Amendment protection for the work of political cartoonists such as Patrick Oliphant, featuring Roslyn Mazer, counsel for the American Association of Editorial Cartoonists during the Hustler v. Falwell litigation, and Leslie Kendrick, Vice Dean of the University of Virginia School of Law. Box lunches will be served. For more information, please contact Rebecca Klaff at rklaff@law.virginia.edu or 434-924-6424.

Signed books will be available for purchase at this event.

Transportation

Shuttle

Parking at the University of Virginia is limited; for your convenience, shuttles have been arranged between the Boar’s Head Inn, the Graduate Hotel, the University Library, the School of Law, and the Downtown Mall. 

In addition, Charlottesville Area Transit offers a free trolley service. 

Shuttle schedules (PDF): 

  • For guests staying at The Graduate hotel
  • For guests staying at The Boar's Head Inn

 

Parking

As noted, during the academic semester parking on Grounds can be limited. We encourage guests to take advantage of the shuttle service and/or public transportation.

Violet Crown: parking in downtown Charlottesville can be limited; read more about parking options. 

Harrison/Small: Parking for Harrison/Small is available in the Central Grounds Parking Garage, 400 Emmet St. After parking, please note your license plate number and visit one of the paystations.

Law School: Parking is available in the D2 and D3 lots adjacent to the Law School. A permit is not required on September 26.

Things to do

If you find you have free time during your visit, there are any number of things to see and do. UVA’s “Plan Your Visit” site is a good place to start for more information, and the University also maintains an event schedule calendar. We particularly recommend the Fralin Museum of Art and the Kluge-Ruhe Aboriginal Art Collection.
